MA 104: Ordinary Differential Equations - Lecture 12

Related: MA 104 Course Overview | Lecture 11 - MA104

Laplace Transform of Derivatives

Theorem: Let $f:[0,\infty)\to\mathbb{R}$ be continuous and of exponential order $\alpha$. Let $f'$ be piecewise continuous on $[0,\infty)$. Then for $s>\alpha$, $$ \mathcal{L}\{f'(t)\}(s) = s\mathcal{L}\{f(t)\}(s) - f(0) $$ General formula (nth derivative): $$ \mathcal{L}\{f^{(k)}(t)\}(s) = s^k \mathcal{L}\{f(t)\}(s) - s^{k-1}f(0) - s^{k-2}f'(0) - \cdots - f^{(k-1)}(0) $$ Proof sketch (integration by parts on intervals between discontinuities) leads to the boundary term $-f(0)$ and the factor $s$ from differentiating $e^{-st}$. Example (second derivative): $$ \mathcal{L}\{y''\} = s^2 Y(s) - s y(0) - y'(0) $$

Solving Constant-Coefficient IVPs

General IVP: $$ a y'' + b y' + c y = r(t), \quad y(0)=k_0,\ y'(0)=k_1 $$

Take Laplace transform: $$ (a s^2 + b s + c) Y(s) = \mathcal{L}\{r(t)\} + (a s + b) k0 + a k1 $$ $$ Y(s) = \frac{\mathcal{L}\{r(t)\} + (a s + b) k0 + a k1}{a s^2 + b s + c} $$ Invert using partial fractions or tables.

Example: $$ y'' - y = t, \quad y(0)=1,\ y'(0)=1 $$ $$ Y(s) = \frac{1 + s + 1}{s^2 - 1} = \frac{s+2}{s^2-1} $$ $$ y(t) = e^t + \sinh t - t $$

Unit Step (Heaviside) Function

Definition: $$ u_a(t) = \begin{cases} 0 & 0 \leq t < a \\ 1 & t \geq a \end{cases} = u_0(t-a) $$ Laplace: $$ \mathcal{L}\{u_a(t)\}(s) = \frac{e^{-a s}}{s}, \quad s>0 $$ Piecewise functions via steps:
  • $f(t) = f_1(t) + u_{t_1}(t)[f_2(t) - f_1(t)] + \cdots$

Second Shifting Theorem

If $\mathcal{L}\{f(t)\}(s) = F(s)$ for $s > s0$ and $a>0$, then $$ \mathcal{L}\{ua(t) f(t-a)\}(s) = e^{-a s} F(s), \quad s > s_0 $$

Equivalently: $$ \mathcal{L}\{u_a(t) g(t)\}(s) = e^{-a s} G(s) \quad \text{where } G(s)=\mathcal{L}\{g(t+a)\} $$

Inverse form: $$ \mathcal{L}^{-1}\{e^{-a s} F(s)\}(t) = u_a(t) f(t-a) $$

Convolution Theorem

Definition (Convolution): $$ (f * g)(t) = \int_0^t f(\tau) g(t-\tau)\, d\tau $$ Theorem: $$ \mathcal{L}\{f * g\}(s) = \mathcal{L}\{f\}(s) \cdot \mathcal{L}\{g\}(s) $$ $$ \mathcal{L}^{-1}\{F(s) G(s)\}(t) = (f * g)(t) $$ Proof (change of order of integration + Fubini). Properties:
  • Commutative, associative, distributive.
  • $f * 0 = 0$, $f * 1 = \int_0^t f(\tau)\, d\tau$.

Derivative & Integration of Laplace Transform

Differentiation in s: $$ \mathcal{L}\{t f(t)\}(s) = - \frac{d}{ds} F(s) $$ $$ \mathcal{L}\{t^n f(t)\}(s) = (-1)^n \frac{d^n}{ds^n} F(s) $$ Integration in s: $$ \mathcal{L}\left\{\frac{f(t)}{t}\right\}(s) = \int_s^\infty F(u)\, du \quad (\text{if limit exists as } t\to 0^+) $$

Summary of Lecture 12

  • Derivatives: Transform turns $y'' \to s^2 Y - s y(0) - y'(0)$.
  • Constant-coefficient IVPs: Algebraic solution + inverse.
  • Unit step: Models jumps/discontinuities; enables piecewise forcing.
  • Second shifting: Handles delayed functions via $e^{-as} F(s)$.
  • Convolution: Product in s-domain ‚Üî convolution in t-domain.
  • s-domain operations: Differentiation/integration give multiplication/division by t.
Key Advantage: Laplace handles initial conditions and piecewise/discontinuous forcing elegantly.
